data: Comprehensive collection of archaeological material discovered at the site of Agrigento and in Agrigento province, organised both by chronology and type across a number of rooms and corridors
Contrada San Nicola, 12 Valley of the Temples, 92100 - Agrigento (AG)
Dedication to the Concordia of the Agrigentines
Seven lines of large Latin letters, centred on the stone. The planning of the text is uneven, with awkward word-breaks (lines 1-2 and 3-4, and some compression at line end, especially line 5

Tall, slightly curved letters, mostly with minimal serifs. P is open; R is closed with long tail; E has short horizontals of equal length, slightly upward curving; M is four equal slanting strokes. In line 5 the O and C of 'procos' are intelinked, and the following O is small and mid-line. A large diagonal upward stroke is visible above the first letter of each of the civic ethnics; and a horizontal above the Q at the end of line 6. The letters all show traces of dark paint (modern?).
Wilson, 1990, Sicily under the Roman Empire: the archaeology of a Roman province, 36 B.C. - A.D. 535
Manganaro, 1988, La Sicilia da Sesto Pompeo a Diocleziano
Salmeri, 1984, Un magister ovium di Domizia Longina in Sicilia

Five lines of latin letters with guidelines marked out for a sixth also. The text is centred, but slightly off the horizontal; hedera/interpuncts mark the line ends.

The letters show the beginnings of a shift towards the later cursive style, with extended serifs on the A and M, T tending to be narrow with upward sloping head, E likewise tall, narrow, with top stroke sloping upwards. Interpuncts, sometimes in the form of hedera, used between all words except after Calbentius

A single line of deep cut very regular Greek letters with some traces of stucco preserved within the letters (and elsewhere on the stone)

Regular letters, deep cut without serifs. Epsilon has equal length bars; P has equal vertical strokes and no overhang on the horizontal; omega is closed (some variation on the position of the horizontal) and slightly smaller than the other letters; alpha has straight bar. There is a circular interpunct and space before the final letter.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2015-11-10

1ἐπὶ δυῶν ἀνδρῶν (vac.1)· (vac.1)Λ [---]
Four lines of Greek letters, all crudely incised in the epigraphic field on the front face.

The first two lines are deeply incised, the second two very lightly incised. Alpha has straight bar, with an apex; epsilon has equal length horizontals; mu in line 3 has extended apices, in anticipation of the cursive form; omicron is circular in lines 1 and 3, angular (made up of straight lines) in lines 3 and 4; sigma is and open four bar sigma in lines 1-2, a quadrate lunate sigma in lines 3-4; phi has a small elongated eye; omega is open in lines 1-2, lunate in line 4. It is therefore likely that lines 1-2 were incised by a different hand from lines 3-4.
Potentially lines 1-2 (Hellenistic) predate lines 3-4 (late Hellenistic or Roman) by a century or two.

Appears to be of a form belonging to the later Roman period.

Two lines of Greek letters, across the middle of the front face. The letters are aligned on the left margin, and are arranged in pseudo-stoichedon, i.e. vertically aligned.

Letters of the early Hellenistic or late classical period. Phi has an elliptical eye; alpha has straight bar; omicron is almost full size; sigma has widely diverging top and bottom strokes; theta is smaller than other letters, with a dot in the middle; omega is open; mu has diverging first and last strokes, and the mid-point only descends half-way; epsilon has short middle stroke. Words are separated on both lines by a three vertical points.
Photo J. Prag, courtesy Agrigento Museo Regionale Archeologico Pietro Griffo
Gabrici, 1876-, Notizie degli scavi di antichità

Remains of 16 densely packed lines of Greek, with the left margin intact; the faint suggestion of a raised border in the lower left corner implies that the final line preserved may be the final line of the text.

Deep cut, small regular square letters, without serifs. Alpha has broken bar; omicron is full size; omega is closed, smaller circle atop a horizontal bar; theta slightly ovoid; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes.
Calderone, 1985, Frammento di decreto onorifico agrigentino

Two dedications to a Caesar by the Annii
Three lines of Latin letters centred on each of front and rear face, first line larger in both cases

The letters are neatly cut, with short serifs. P is open on both texts, R is closed. Text A has tall I in line three. The primary difference between Text A and Text B is in the technique, with the letters in A having a flat cut, whereas B is engraved with a more elegant 'v-cut' and more elegant interpuncts. It is likely that the two were carved by different stone-masons.
De Miro, 1984-1985, L'attivita della soprintendenza archeologica di Agrigento (Anni 1980-84)

Greek letters fill the height of the rim in a single line
Neat, regular deeply incised letters with pronounced terminations to the strokes and a broad module. Alpha has straight bar; epsilon has slightly shorter middle bar.
second or early first century BCE

Three letters filling the sloping face of the rim
Thinly incised, regular and broad letters, with simple terminations to the strokes. Alpha with straight bar, pi with equal verticals, slighly over-hanging horizontal.

Worn, thinly incised lunate letters. Alpha with crossbar descending to left; lunate epsilon; lunate omega; kappa with short bars.

Remains of four lines of Greek letters, filling what is left of the face of the stone.
Neat reguular v-cut lettes with simple serifs. Alpha has extension at the top; epsilon is lunate; kappa has full length arms; lunate sigma; uncial omega; phi has rhomboid eye.

Dedication by a curator of the res publica Liparitanorum
The remains of six evenly spaced lines of Latin letters are preserved, with a regular left margin; the right margin is not preserved for any line

The letters are well cut in a relatively refined v-cut, with modest serifs. The letters are tend towards the tall and narrow and are very regular and evenly spaced.  P and R are open, O is somewhat ovoid, E has bars of equal length, D is quite full, the diagonal of the N does not always start from the top of the first hasta. Interpuncts are not consistently used, with one elegant example in line 2
later 2nd or 3rd century CE (Vallarino on palaeographic grounds)
Vallarino, 2017, L'epigrafe dall'area del Tempio ellenistico-romano
